question: A recent study of different measures of left ventricular function gave the following results for mean values in the (healthy) study group: Mean ejection fraction 59%, mean systolic shortening of the left ventricle: 17 mm, mean systolic tissue velocity: 9.1 cm/s and mean systolic strain rate (shortening velocity per length unit) – 1.1 s-1To compare the usefulness of the different measures, we look at the reproducibility of the results, doing repeated measurements. Which measure of repeatability would be best here for comparison of the accuracy of the different measures?
options: Limits of agreement
Correlation
Mean error
kappa coefficient

question: Ejection fraction measured by ultrasound has a high variability. Limits of agreement are ± 10% points. A patient who has had an infarct had an ejection fraction of 45% (slightly reduced) when he left the hospital. Two months later, he was admitted because of dyspnea, but had no new infarction. During the second stay, a new echocardiography was made, and they now found an EF of 38%. The diagnosis of worsening heart failure (HF) was made, and medical treatment for heart failure was started. The conclusion that the patient had worsening heart failure was:
options: Correct because the EF was below 40%
Correct because the EF had dropped by 7% points
Incorrect because a change of 7% points is not a significant change with this method
Incorrect because an EF of 38% is not compatible with heart failure.

question: What is the sensitivity of a certain diagnostic test?
options: The probability of having a positive test if you are ill
The probability of having a negative test if you are healthy
The probability of being ill if you have a positive test
The probability of being healthy if you have a negative test

question: What do we mean by the positive predictive value of a test:
options: The probability of being ill if the test shows the patient to be ill
The probability of being healthy, if the test shows the patient to be healthy
The probability of being ill, despite the test showing the patient to be healthy
The probability of being healthy, despite the test showing the patient to be ill

question: What is this?
options: False positive diagnosis
False negative diagnosis
Over diagnosis
Over treatment

question: The usefulness of a diagnostic test is dependent on it’s ability to separate a healthy population from the population with the disease that the test is specific for. Validity is the bias of the test measure from the “truth”. Reliability or precision is the statistical spread of repeated measurements. Which factor is most important for the diagnostic usefulness?
options: The validity of the test
The reliability of the test
Both are equally important
None of them

question: 8. A 50 year old man with no symptoms want a checkup to be sure he doesn’t have coronary heart disease, for safety’s sake. He went to a private specialist centre in order to have a test, and have an exercise ECG. The risk of having significant coronary disease in men without symptoms at that age may be assumed to be 4%. Exercise ECG has a sensitivity of about 65%, and a specificity of 75%. This may be expressed in the following 4x4 table: If the test shows a positive result (meaning it indicates coronary disease), what is the positive predictive value of this test (the probability that he really is ill)?

A man in his mid fifties go to a doctor to check if he has prostate cancer, and asks for a blood test (PSA) that marks the presence of this. He has a blood level of PSA of 10 ng/l, which means that it is elevated. With a cut of of 4 ng/l, the test has a sensitivity of 20% and a specificity of 90%. The prevalence of prostate cancer among men between 50 and 60 years can be taken as about 1 %. What is the probability that he has cancer (positive predictive value of the test)?
What is “downstream damage” from a diagnostic screening program?
options: Long term radiation damage from excessive X-ray use
As screening do not result in reduction of total mortality, the downstream damage is the statistical effect that the patients will have to die from something else
The fact that screening programs use resources that could have been used better for treatment of other patients, those patients suffer from downstream damage of lack of optimal treatment
The fact that screening results in over diagnosis – patients with harmless disease, but who will receive treatment, which will in some cases have side effects.

question: What is evidence based medical practice?
options: Practice that is founded in solid physiological experiments as evidence
Practice that is only founded in clinical studies
Practice that takes into account both clinical studies, medical background knowledge and patients experience and preferences
Practice that is founded on large epidemiological studies
